=== Law === {{Main|Legal abuse}} Legal bullying is the bringing of a [[Vexatious litigation|vexatious legal action]] to control and punish a person. Legal bullying can often take the form of frivolous, repetitive, or burdensome lawsuits brought to intimidate the defendant into submitting to the litigant's request, not because of the legal merit of the litigant's position, but principally due to the defendant's inability to maintain the legal battle. This can also take the form of [[Strategic Lawsuit Against Public Participation]] (SLAPP). It was partially concern about the potential for this kind of abuse that helped to fuel the [[protests against SOPA and PIPA]] in the United States in 2011 and 2012.{{citation needed|date=August 2020}}
=== Military === {{Main|Bullying in the military|Dedovshchina}} In 2000, the UK [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] (MOD) defined bullying as "the use of physical strength or the [[abuse of authority]] to intimidate or victimize others, or to give unlawful punishments".<ref>{{cite book | last =Dannatt | first =Sir Richard | title =Values and Standards of the British Army | chapter =Lawful: Paragraph 20 | publisher =the British Army | year =2008 | chapter-url =http://www.army.mod.uk/documents/general/v_s_of_the_british_army.pdf | access-date =2013-10-29 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130817150435/http://www.army.mod.uk/documents/general/v_s_of_the_british_army.pdf | archive-date =2013-08-17 }}</ref>
Some argue that this behaviour should be allowed, due to ways in which "soldiering" is different from other occupations. Soldiers expected to risk their lives should, according to them, develop strength of body and spirit to accept bullying.<ref name="CallaghanKernic2003">{{cite book|author1=Jean M. Callaghan|author2=Franz Kernic|title=Armed Forces and International Security: Global Trends and Issues|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tvnCKuSdOEwC&pg=PA19|access-date=2013-10-29|year=2003|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-8258-7227-4|pages=19–|chapter=Chapter 2: "Social Psychology" of the Individual Soldier|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101120837/http://books.google.com/books?id=tvnCKuSdOEwC&pg=PA19|archive-date=2014-01-01}}</ref>
=== Parenting === {{See also|Child abuse|Narcissistic parent|Parental narcissistic abuse}} Parents who may [[Displacement (psychology)|displace]] their anger, insecurity, or a persistent need to dominate and [[Abusive power and control|control]] upon their children in excessive ways have been proven to increase the likelihood that their own children will in turn become overly aggressive or controlling towards their peers.<ref name="parent bullying">{{cite web | last =Priesnitz | first =Wendy | title =Parental Bullying Creates Bullies | work =Natural Child Magazine | publisher =Wendy Priesnitz | url =http://www.naturalchildmagazine.com/news/parental_bullying_creates_bullies.htm | access-date =2013-10-29 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20131031134551/http://www.naturalchildmagazine.com/news/parental_bullying_creates_bullies.htm | archive-date =2013-10-31 }}</ref> The [[American Psychological Association]] advises on its website that parents who may suspect their own children may be engaging in bullying activities among their peers should carefully consider the examples which they themselves may be setting for their own children regarding how they typically interact with their own peers, colleagues, and children.<ref name = "APA on parental bullying">{{cite web | title =Bullying: How parents, teachers, and kids can take action to prevent bullying | work =American Psychological Association | url = http://www.apa.org/helpcenter/bullying.aspx | access-date = 2013-10-29}}</ref>
=== Prison === {{Main|Prisoner abuse}} The prison environment is known for bullying. An additional complication is the staff and their relationships with the inmates. Thus, the following possible bullying scenarios are possible: * Inmate bullies inmate (echoing school bullying) * Staff bullies inmate * Staff bullies staff (a manifestation of workplace bullying) * Inmate bullies staff
=== School === {{Main|School bullying}} [[File:CDC DASH anti-bullying PSA.jpg|thumb|A [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] graphic presenting school anti-bullying guidelines]] It is important to distinguish school bullying that per definition has the goal of harming the victim from normal peer conflict that is an inherent part of everyday school life and often promotes social development.<ref name="School bullying is not a conflict"/> Unlike normal conflict, bullying is a systematic and repeated abuse committed intentionally by another student who has more power (physical, social, or otherwise). School bullies may taunt and tease their target before finally physically bullying them. Bystanders typically choose to either participate or watch, sometimes out of fear of becoming the next target.
Bullying can occur in nearly any part in or around the school building, although it may occur more frequently during physical education classes and activities such as recess. Bullying also takes place in school hallways, bathrooms, on school buses and while waiting for buses, and in classes that require group work and/or after school activities. Bullying in school sometimes consists of a group of students taking advantage of or isolating one student in particular and gaining the loyalty of bystanders who want to avoid becoming the next target. The 2011 documentary [[Bully (2011 film)|''Bully'']] showcases the lives of five American public school students who face bullying in school and while on the school bus. The bullying is shown to affect the students both at school and in their homes.
Teachers play an important role in bullying prevention and intervention because they are the adults who spend most of their time with the students.<ref name="dx.doi.org">{{cite journal | vauthors=Burger C, Strohmeier D, Kollerová L | journal=Journal of Youth and Adolescence | title=Teachers can make a difference in bullying: Effects of teacher interventions on students' adoption of bully, victim, bully-victim or defender roles across time | date= 2022 | volume=51 | issue=12 | pages=2312–2327 | issn=0047-2891 | doi=10.1007/s10964-022-01674-6| pmid=36053439 | pmc=9596519 | s2cid=252009527 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors=Yoon JS, Kerber K | journal=Research in Education | title=Bullying: Elementary teachers' attitudes and intervention strategies | volume=69 | issue=1 | pages=27–35 | date= 2003 | issn=0034-5237 | doi=10.7227/rie.69.3| s2cid=219984495 }}</ref> Bullying can, however, also be perpetrated by teachers and the school system itself; there is an inherent power differential in the system that can easily predispose to subtle or covert abuse ([[relational aggression]] or [[passive aggression]]), [[humiliation]], or exclusion—even while maintaining overt commitments to anti-bullying policies.<ref name="GarbarinodeLara2003">{{cite book|author1=James Garbarino|author2=Ellen deLara|title=And Words Can Hurt Forever: How to Protect Adolescents from Bullying, Harassment, and Emotional Violence|url=https://archive.org/details/andwordscanhurtf00garb|url-access=registration|access-date=2013-10-29|date=2 September 2003|publisher=Free Press|isbn=978-0-7432-2899-2}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Witted |first=Kathryn Suzanne |title=Student Reports of Physical and Psychological Maltreatment in Schools: An Under Explored Aspect of Student Victimization in Schools |work=PhD dissertation, University of Tennessee |year=2005 |url=http://trace.tennessee.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3874&context=utk_graddiss |access-date=2013-10-29 |url-status=live |archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20131031121558/http://trace.tennessee.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3874&context=utk_graddiss |archive-date=2013-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1177/0013124507304487 |title=Do Teachers Bully Students?: Findings From a Survey of Students in an Alternative Education Setting |year=2007 |last1=Whitted |first1=K. S. |last2=Dupper |first2=D. R. |journal=Education and Urban Society |volume=40 |pages=329–341|issue=3|s2cid=143894407 }}</ref>
In 2016, in Canada, a North American legal precedent was set by a mother and her son, after the son was bullied in his public school. The mother and son won a court case against the Ottawa-Carleton District School Board, making this the first case in North America where a school board has been found negligent in a bullying case for failing to meet the standard of care (the "duty of care" that the school board owes to its students). Thus, it sets a precedent of a school board being found liable in negligence for harm caused to a child, because they failed to protect a child from the bullying actions of other students. There has been only one other similar bullying case and it was won in Australia in 2013 (''Oyston v. St. Patricks College'', 2013).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ottawacommunitynews.com/news-story/6773614-family-wins-precedent-setting-case-against-public-school-board/ |title=Ottawa News | Latest Information, Updates & Articles | Ottawa Citizen |access-date=2016-07-22 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210080755/http://www.ottawacommunitynews.com/news-story/6773614-family-wins-precedent-setting-case-against-public-school-board/ |archive-date=2017-02-10 }}</ref>
=== Heterosexuality === {{Main|Sexual bullying}} {{See also|Slut-shaming}} Sexual bullying is "any bullying behaviour, whether physical or non-physical, that is based on a person's sexuality or gender. It is when sexuality or gender is used as a weapon by boys or girls towards other boys or girls – although it is more commonly directed at girls. It can be carried out to a person's face, behind their back or through the use of technology."<ref name=NSPCC02>{{cite web |url=http://w1.qehs.net/moodle2/pluginfile.php/10744/mod_resource/content/1/Sexual%20bullying.pdf |title=The NSPCC working definition of Sexual Bullying |publisher=[[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children|NSPCC]] |access-date=13 September 2016 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220065205/http://w1.qehs.net/moodle2/pluginfile.php/10744/mod_resource/content/1/Sexual%20bullying.pdf |archive-date=20 December 2016 }}</ref>
=== Transsexuality === {{Main|Trans bashing}} Trans bashing is the act of [[victimizing]] a person physically, sexually, or verbally because they are [[transgender]] or [[Transsexualism|transsexual]].<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,20774504-5005961,00.html Guilty plea over transsexual bashing] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502173830/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0%2C21985%2C20774504-5005961%2C00.html |date=2008-05-02 }} By Mariza O'Keefe in ''Herald Sun''</ref> Unlike [[gay bashing]], it is committed because of the target's actual or perceived [[gender identity]], not [[sexual orientation]].
=== Work === {{Main|Workplace bullying}} Workplace bullying occurs when an employee experiences a persistent pattern of mistreatment from others in the workplace that causes harm.<ref>Rayner, C. & Keashley, L. (2005). Bullying at work: A perspective from Britain and North America. In S. Fox & P. E. Spector (eds.) Counterproductive work behavior: Investigations of actors and targets (pp. 271-296). Washington DC: American Psychological Association.</ref> Workplace bullying can include such tactics as [[verbal abuse|verbal]], [[nonverbal]], [[psychological abuse|psychological]], [[physical abuse|physical]] abuse and [[humiliation]]. This type of [[workplace aggression]] is particularly difficult because, unlike the typical forms of [[school bullying]], workplace bullies often operate within the established rules and policies of their organization and their society. Bullying in the workplace is in the majority of cases reported as having been perpetrated by someone in authority over the target. Bullies can also be peers, and occasionally can be subordinates.<ref>Rayner, C., & Cooper, C. L. (2006). Workplace Bullying. In Kelloway, E., Barling, J. & Hurrell Jr., J. (eds.), Handbook of workplace violence (pp. 47-90). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.</ref>
The first known documented use of "workplace bullying" is in 1992 in a book by [[Andrea Adams]] called ''Bullying at Work: How to Confront and Overcome It''.<ref> [https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=workplace+bullying&case_insensitive=on&year_start=1990&year_end=2008&corpus=15&smoothing=3&share=&direct_url=t4%3B%2Cworkplace%20bullying%3B%2Cc0%3B%2Cs0%3B%3Bworkplace%20bullying%3B%2Cc0%3B%3BWorkplace%20Bullying%3B%2Cc0%3B%3BWorkplace%20bullying%3B%2Cc0 Google ngrams]</ref><ref>[[Andrea Adams|Adams, Andrea]] with contributions from Crawford, Neil ''Bullying at Work: How to Confront and Overcome It'' (1992)</ref>
Research has also investigated the impact of the larger organizational context on bullying as well as the group-level processes that impact on the incidence, and maintenance of bullying behavior.<ref>Ramsay, S., Troth, A & Branch, S. (2010). Work-place bullying: A group processes framework ''Journal of Occupational and Organizational Psychology, 84(4), 799-816.''</ref> Bullying can be covert or overt. It may be missed by superiors or known by many throughout the organization. Negative effects are not limited to the targeted individuals, and may lead to a decline in [[employee morale]] and a change in [[organizational culture]].<ref name="SilentEpidemic" /> A [[Cochrane (organisation)|Cochrane Collaboration]] [[systematic review]] has found very low quality [[Scientific evidence|evidence]] to suggest that organizational and individual interventions may prevent bullying behaviors in the workplace.<ref>{{Cite journal|volume = 1|pages = CD009778|last1=Gillen|first1=Patricia A|last2=Sinclair|first2=Marlene|last3=Kernohan|first3=W George|last4=Begley|first4=Cecily M|last5=Luyben|first5=Ans G|date=2017-01-30|doi=10.1002/14651858.cd009778.pub2|pmid = 28134445|pmc = 6464940|title = Interventions for prevention of bullying in the workplace|journal = Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews| issue=1 }}</ref>
==== Academia ==== {{Main|Bullying in academia}} Bullying in academia is workplace bullying of scholars and staff in academia, especially places of higher education such as colleges and universities. It is believed to be common, although has not received as much attention from researchers as bullying in some other contexts.<ref> {{cite journal | last1 =Keashly | first1 =Loraleigh | last2 =Neuman | first2 =Joel H. | title =Faculty Experiences with Bullying in Higher Education - Causes, Consequences, and Management | journal =Administrative Theory & Praxis | volume =32 | issue =1 | pages =48–70 | year =2010 | url =http://www.ccas.net/files/ADVANCE/Keashly_Bullying.pdf | doi =10.2753/ATP1084-1806320103 | s2cid =142766958 | access-date =2013-10-29 | url-status =live | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20131031193910/http://www.ccas.net/files/ADVANCE/Keashly_Bullying.pdf | archive-date =2013-10-31 }}</ref>
==== Blue-collar jobs ==== Bullying has been identified as prominent in blue-collar jobs, including on oil rigs and in mechanic shops and machine shops. It is thought that intimidation and fear of retribution cause decreased incident reports. In industry sectors dominated by males, typically of little education, where disclosure of incidents are seen as effeminate, reporting in the socioeconomic and cultural milieu of such industries would likely lead to a [[vicious circle]]. This is often used in combination with [[Manipulation (psychology)|manipulation]] and [[coercion]] of facts to gain favour among higher-ranking [[administrator (business)|administrators]].<ref> {{cite journal | last1 =Notelaers | first1 =Guy | last2 =Vermunt | first2 =Jeroen K. | last3 =Baillien | first3 =Elfi | last4 =Einarsen | first4 =Ståle | last5 =De Witte | first5 =Hans | title =Exploring Risk Groups Workplace Bullying with Categorical Data | journal =Industrial Health | volume =49 | issue =1 | pages =73–88 | year =2011 | url =https://unimaas.academia.edu/GuyNotelaers/Papers/278637/Exploring_Risk_Groups_and_Risk_Factors_for_Workplace_Bullying | access-date =2013-10-29 | doi =10.2486/indhealth.ms1155 | pmid =20823631 | url-status =live | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20120425093442/http://unimaas.academia.edu/GuyNotelaers/Papers/278637/Exploring_Risk_Groups_and_Risk_Factors_for_Workplace_Bullying | archive-date =2012-04-25 | doi-access =free }}</ref>
==== Information technology ==== {{Main|Bullying in information technology}} A culture of bullying is common in information technology (IT), leading to high sickness rates, low morale, poor productivity, and high staff-turnover.<ref>{{cite web | last =Thomson | first =Rebecca | title =IT profession blighted by bullying | work =ComputerWeekly.com: Feature | publisher =TechTarget | url =http://www.computerweekly.com/feature/IT-profession-blighted-by-bullying | access-date =2013-10-29 | url-status =live | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20131029225711/http://www.computerweekly.com/feature/IT-profession-blighted-by-bullying | archive-date =2013-10-29 }}</ref> Deadline-driven project work and stressed-out managers take their toll on IT workers.<ref name="RichardsEdwards2008">{{cite book|author1=Ann Richards|author2=Sharon L. Edwards|title=A Nurse's Survival Guide to the Ward|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ytmEHQjia0AC|access-date=2013-10-29|year=2008|publisher=Churchill Livingstone|isbn=978-0-443-06897-3|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101122142/http://books.google.com/books?id=ytmEHQjia0AC|archive-date=2014-01-01}}</ref>
==== Courts ==== {{Main|Bullying in the legal profession}} Bullying in the [[legal profession]] is believed to be more common than in some other professions. It is believed that its adversarial, hierarchical tradition contributes towards this.<ref>[http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/t1_le_mire_and_owens.pdf Le Mire, Suzanne; Owens, Rosemary ''A propitious moment?: Workplace bullying and regulation of the legal profession'' University of New South Wales Law Journal, The Volume 37 Issue 3 (Dec 2014)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201001112/http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/t1_le_mire_and_owens.pdf |date=2015-02-01 }}</ref> Women, trainees and solicitors who have been qualified for five years or less are more affected, as are ethnic minority lawyers and lesbian, gay and bisexual lawyers.<ref>[http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1009923.aspx Society publishes guidance on tackling bullying in solicitor profession] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201001313/http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1009923.aspx |date=2015-02-01 }} The Journal of the Law Society of Scotland 27 June 2011</ref>
==== Medicine ==== {{Main|Bullying in medicine|Bullying in nursing}} Bullying in the [[medical profession]] is common, particularly of student or trainee doctors and of nurses. It is thought that this is at least in part an outcome of conservative traditional hierarchical structures and teaching methods in the medical profession, which may result in a bullying cycle.
Even though The [[American Nurses Association]] believes that all nursing personnel have the right to work in safe, non-abusive environments, bullying has been identified as being particularly prevalent in the nursing profession although the reasons are not clear. It is thought that relational aggression (psychological aspects of bullying such as gossiping and intimidation) are relevant. Relational aggression has been studied among girls but not so much among adult women.<ref name="RichardsEdwards2008"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nursingworld.org/Bullying-Workplace-Violence |title=Violence, Incivility, & Bullying |date=14 October 2017 |publisher=American Nurses Association |access-date=21 April 2022}}; {{cite journal | last =Dellasega | first =Cheryl A. | title =Bullying Among Nurses | journal =American Journal of Nursing | volume =109 | issue =1 | pages =52–58 | year =2009 | doi =10.1097/01.NAJ.0000344039.11651.08 | pmid =19112267 }}</ref>
==== Teaching ==== {{Main|Bullying in teaching}} [[School]] [[teachers]] are commonly the subject of bullying but they are also sometimes the originators of bullying within a school environment.
=== Machines === Children have been observed bullying anthropomorphic robots designed to assist the elderly. Their attacks start with blocking the robots' paths of movement and then escalate to verbal abuse, hitting and destroying the object. Seventy-five percent of the kids interviewed perceived the robot as "human-like" yet decided to abuse it anyway, while 35% of the kids who beat up the robot did so "for enjoyment".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/kids-attack-bully-robot-japanese-mall-danger-avoidance-ai-2015-8?IR=T|title=Scientists are teaching robots to avoid children — because kids can be surprisingly mean|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-11-02}}</ref>
== Prevention == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:File-Bully Prevention.jpg|thumbnail|right|October is the month used to educate and raise awareness to prevent bullying. ]] --> Bullying prevention is the collective effort to prevent, reduce and stop bullying.<ref>{{cite book |author=((National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine)) |editor1-last=Rivara|editor1-first=Frederick|editor2-last=Suzanne|editor2-first=Le Menestrel|title=Preventing Bullying Through Science, Policy, and Practice|date=2016|publisher=[[National Academies Press]]|isbn=978-0-309-44067-7|doi=10.17226/23482|pmid=27748087|s2cid=156853266 |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/23482/preventing-bullying-through-science-policy-and-practice|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160518032731/http://www.nap.edu/catalog/23482/preventing-bullying-through-science-policy-and-practice|archive-date=2016-05-18}}</ref> Many campaigns and events are designated to bullying prevention throughout the world. Bullying prevention campaigns and events include [[Anti-Bullying Day]], [[Anti-Bullying Week]], [[International Day of Pink]], [[International STAND UP to Bullying Day]] and [[National Bullying Prevention Month]]. [[anti-bullying legislation|Anti-bullying laws]] in the U.S. have also been enacted in 23 of its 50 states, making bullying in schools illegal.<ref>{{cite journal | pmc = 2791686 | pmid=20514181 | doi=10.1901/jaba.2009.42-747 | volume=42 | issue=4 | title=Bully prevention in positive behavior support. | year=2009 | pages=747–59 | journal=Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis | last1 = Ross | first1 = SW | last2 = Horner | first2 = RH}}</ref>
A 2019 study by McCallion & Feder found that school-based anti-bullying programs may lower the incidence of bullying by 25%.<ref>{{Cite web |title=TXABC |url=https://www.txabc.org/ |access-date=2023-11-09 |website=TXABC |language=en-US}}</ref>
Bullying prevention programs allow schools to help decrease cyberbullying within he realm of school. The prevention methods are targeted mainly for middle schoolers, where we see the most bullying occur.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Wölfer |first1=Ralf |last2=Schultze-Krumbholz |first2=Anja |last3=Zagorscak |first3=Pavle |last4=Jäkel |first4=Anne |last5=Göbel |first5=Kristin |last6=Scheithauer |first6=Herbert |date=December 2014 |title=Prevention 2.0: Targeting Cyberbullying @ School |url=http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s11121-013-0438-y |journal=Prevention Science |language=en |volume=15 |issue=6 |pages=879–887 |doi=10.1007/s11121-013-0438-y |pmid=24122481 |s2cid=22915480 |issn=1389-4986}}</ref> To help decrease cyberbullying, people need to take preventative measures. One preventative method was implemented to determine the effectiveness against cyberbullying. This program called "Media Heroes" showed how educating teachers on bullying behaviors in school can help them educate and stop students from bullying. This educational program decreased bullying in their schools. Having trusted adults become educated on what can go on online, can help prevent further cyberbullying.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Wölfer |first1=Ralf |last2=Schultze-Krumbholz |first2=Anja |last3=Zagorscak |first3=Pavle |last4=Jäkel |first4=Anne |last5=Göbel |first5=Kristin |last6=Scheithauer |first6=Herbert |date=2014-12-01 |title=Prevention 2.0: Targeting Cyberbullying @ School |journal=Prevention Science |language=en |volume=15 |issue=6 |pages=879–887 |doi=10.1007/s11121-013-0438-y |pmid=24122481 |s2cid=22915480 |issn=1573-6695|url=https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:4869203e-568d-4ee3-973c-6c1cac275bb5 }}</ref>
== Responses == Bullying is typically ongoing and not isolated behaviour. Common responses are to try to ignore it, to confront the bullies, or to turn to an authority figure.
Ignoring it often does nothing to stop the bullying continuing, and it can become worse over time.<ref>W. Craig et al., [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0143034307084136 "Responding to bullying, what works"]</ref> It can be important to address bullying behaviour early on, as it can be easier to control the earlier it is detected.<ref>W. Ci, [https://carleton.ca/economics/wp-content/uploads/bullying_paper_1-6.pdf "What can be done to stop bullying among children? Evidence from Canada"]</ref> Bystanders play an important role in responding to bullying, as doing nothing can encourage it to continue, while small steps that oppose the behaviour can reduce it.<ref>Bully-zero Australia Foundation, [http://bzaf.org.au/respond-to-bullying/ "Respond to bullying"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180526185909/http://bzaf.org.au/respond-to-bullying/ |date=2018-05-26 }}</ref>
Authority figures can play an important role, such as parents or teachers in child or adolescent situations, or supervisors, human-resources staff or parent-bodies in workplace and volunteer settings. In the school context, teachers who set clear boundaries, communicate seriously that bullying behavior is unacceptable and will not be tolerated, and involve school administrators have been shown to reduce bullying.<ref name="dx.doi.org"/> Discussing bullying and its consequences with the whole class is also an important intervention that not only reduces bullying, but also encourages other students to step in and stop bullying even before it reaches its full form.<ref name="dx.doi.org"/> In general, authority figures can be influential in recognising and stopping bullying behaviour, and creating an environment that does not encourage or promote bullying.<ref>[https://www.stopbullying.gov/respond/on-the-spot/index.html "Stop bullying on the spot"]</ref><ref>Safe work Australia, [https://www.safeworkaustralia.gov.au/doc/guide-preventing-and-responding-workplace-bullying "Guide for preventing and responding to workplace bullying"]</ref>
In many situations, authority figures are untrained and unqualified, do not know how to respond, and can make the situation worse.<ref>Veronica Birkett, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/bullied-dont-tell-the-teacher-1361862.html "Bullied? Don't tell the teacher"]</ref> In some cases the authority figures even support the people doing the bullying, facilitating it continuing and increasing the isolation and marginalising of the target.<ref>[https://ethicsinvolunteering.wordpress.com/responding-to-bullying-in-arc-unsw-sports/ "Responding to bullying in Arc UNSW sports"]</ref> Some of the most effective ways to respond are to recognise that harmful behaviour is taking place, and to create an environment where it will not continue.<ref name=field03>E. Field, [http://www.aph.gov.au/parliamentary_business/committees/house_of_representatives_committees?url=ee/bullying/subs/sub58.pdf "The prevalence of workplace bullying in Australia"]</ref>
